awd_titl_txt: Optimizing  Openness in Human Participants Research: Harmonizing Standards for Consent Agreements and Data Management Plans to Empower the Reuse of Sensitive Scientific Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent technological advances allow for an increase in the amount of sensitive human participants data that can be safely shared. Institutional Review Boards' (IRBs) traditional reluctance to allow the sharing of such data unnecessarily constrains their long-term reuse. This project seeks to close the gap between modern options for safely sharing sensitive data and IRB practices by establishing socio-technical infrastructure to support a sustained dialogue and productive partnerships between data repositories and IRBs with the objective to pilot new consensus guidance, protocols, and templates on the sharing and long-term re-use of sensitive data generated through research with human participants.

This project is supported by the National Science Foundation Public Access Initiative which is managed by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure on behalf of the Foundation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Scientists are increasingly expected to share their research data. They are also required to protect human subjects by respecting ethical and legal constraints on such sharing. This dual obligation is reflected in the aphorism that data should be "as open as possible, as closed as necessary." 

In the U.S. academic ecosystem, Institutional Review Boards (IRBs) are the primary institutional stakeholder concerned with the "as closed as necessary" part of the aphorism. Customarily, IRBs have interacted directly with scholars early in the research cycle and in isolation from institutions that encourage data sharing and research transparency practices, which often happen after the completion of a project. Mainly focused on protection, IRBs have historically guided scholars to commit to withholding or destroying sensitive research data in documents such as project-specific IRB protocols (including participant consent statements) and broader guidance they have provided. 

In part as a result of IRBs' traditional reluctance to countenance the sharing of sensitive human participants data, these data have often only been available to the researchers who collected them. This situation has presented an obstacle to rigorous and efficient scientific inquiry. Crucially, it hampers the re-use of the rich data generated through interaction with people, impeding discovery and the generation of new scientific knowledge. Not making sensitive data available for re-use prevents funders from realizing greater returns on their research investments. Moreover, for some types of field research, the failure to share sensitive data can negatively impact research participants as well, for example, preventing those who genuinely wish their story to be broadly told from having a voice, or inducing multiple scholars or research teams to call on the same human participants, exhausting them and reflecting poorly on scientific researchers.

The intuition underlying this research project was that some IRB practices might be lagging behind promising developments in data management practices, including the appropriate use of privacy protecting technologies, that would allow for the safe sharing of some sensitive data. Accordingly, rather than a choice between either protecting participants or sharing sensitive human participants' data, there could be occasions when it is possible to achieve both goals. This project was designed to draw IRBs into ongoing conversations about sharing sensitive data ethically and legally--and leveraging their expertise to develop corresponding advice and templates for scholar--in order that more research will be designed to allow the responsible sharing of sensitive human participants data. Through exposure to broader debates about data sharing, and to the concerns, and perspectives of other stakeholders supporting the scholarly research cycle (e.g., data repositories, funders, and publishers), the project was intended to provide IRBs with more information about new technologies and practices that can empower the safe sharing of sensitive data. The long-term goal was the increased availability of hitherto unobtainable sensitive human participants data, facilitating the reuse of those data, and encouraging rigorous and replicable science.     

Project personnel gathered empirical data through interviews and focus groups with IRB personnel and from the analysis of IRB-produced materials; conducted workshops with researchers from several key social science disciplines at their professional organizations' annual conferences, as well as at several meetings of the professional organization of the US-based ethics community; and synthesized good existing practices and new models for appropriate sharing of sensitive data. The project opened several channels for sustained ongoing communication and collaboration among IRBs and data repositories. The team produced guidance in a number of formats, including a glossary, templates, and webinars. The outreach to IRB personnel has presented information on the project's activities to several hundred human ethics personnel at key research-intensive universities across the country and generated useful  feedback from many of them.   

More broadly, by appropriately diminishing obstacles to safe and appropriate data sharing and reuse, the project aimed to facilitate conditions to empower discovery; enhance scientific understanding; increase the accessibility, honesty, rigor, and relevance of scientific research; and facilitate the discovery of research synergies and the formation of research partnerships.
